scriptures.title: Scripture Reading
poem_content: I bow to the inherent pure mind ground,
The endless Buddha store, the Great Compassionate Honored One;
From the southern world, fragrant clouds rise,
Rain of fragrance, rain of flowers, and clouds of flowers;
Jewel rains and jewel clouds of countless kinds,
Devas and humans ask the Buddha the cause,
The Buddha says Ksitigarbha Bodhisattva has arrived;
The Tathagatas of the three times all praise him,
Bodhisattvas of the ten directions all take refuge;
I now plant good roots from past causes,
And praise the true merit of Ksitigarbha.
scriptures.mantra_desc: This mantra is spoken by Ksitigarbha Bodhisattva. Reciting it sincerely can eliminate fixed karma that must otherwise be retributed. It is often found at the beginning (or end) of the 'Sutra of the Past Vows of Ksitigarbha Bodhisattva'.

reader.section_desc: Deeply enter the Sutra Treasury and have wisdom like the sea. The three major scriptures of the Ksitigarbha Dharma door.
reader.sutra_1_desc: The Buddhist Sutra of Filial Piety, detailing Ksitigarbha's great vows and salvation of hell beings.
reader.sutra_2_desc: Expounds the Ten Wheels Dharma door, eliminating karma and increasing blessings.
reader.sutra_3_desc: Divination of good and evil karma, repentance, and seeking pure precepts.

prayer_wall.title: Ten Thousand Heart Lamps · Prayer Wall
prayer_wall.subtitle: Light a heart lamp, make a good vow, illuminate your true nature, and warm the world.

footer.guide_lamp_desc: Lamps represent wisdom. Offering lamps to the Buddha prays for opening wisdom and breaking ignorance.
footer.guide_flower_desc: Flowers represent causes. Planting good causes leads to good results. Prays for dignified appearance and gentle nature.
footer.guide_incense_desc: Incense represents discipline. Purifying body and mind, praying for elimination of karmic obstacles and growth of blessings.
